caps.fact: Coors Banquet was first brewed in 1873 by Adolph Coors in Golden, Colorado.
The beer was originally just called Coors Beer; “Banquet” was a nickname given by miners.
Adolph Coors was a German immigrant who stowed away on a ship to America.
The original Coors brewery was built at the base of the Rocky Mountains to access fresh spring water.
“Banquet” reportedly came from Colorado miners who drank the beer at celebratory banquets after work.
Coors was one of the first breweries to use aluminum cans, helping to popularize them.
The water used in Coors Banquet comes from the Clear Creek watershed.
In its early years, Coors also produced soda, malted milk, and porcelain to stay afloat.
The Coors family originally lived above the brewery in Golden, Colorado.
During Prohibition, Coors survived by selling near beer and manufacturing ceramic products.
Prohibition began in Colorado in 1916, four years before national Prohibition.
Coors developed a product called Manna, a non-alcoholic malted milk.
Adolph Coors Jr. helped transition the company through Prohibition.
The Coors Porcelain division became highly successful, producing labware and industrial ceramics.
Coors reused yeast strains from before Prohibition, preserving its original flavor.
Coors Banquet was sold only west of the Mississippi River until 1981.
Its limited distribution gave Banquet a “forbidden fruit” mystique in the eastern U.S.
The beer was not pasteurized, which limited how far it could be shipped.
Coors pioneered cold filtering as an alternative to pasteurization.
Smuggling Coors east became a pop-culture phenomenon in the 1970s.
The 1977 film “Smokey and the Bandit” centers on smuggling Coors Banquet to Georgia.
President Gerald Ford reportedly had Coors smuggled to him by the Secret Service.
Actor Paul Newman was a fan of Coors Banquet.
Coors Banquet was served at the White House during the Reagan administration.
Clint Eastwood drank Coors Banquet in films like “Every Which Way but Loose.”
Coors Banquet is known for its distinctive stubby bottle.
The stubby bottle is officially called the “Heritage Bottle.”
In the 2000s, Coors leaned into its heritage branding to stand apart from Coors Light.
The Banquet label has featured the Rocky Mountains since the 1940s.
Its gold-and-brown branding conveys ruggedness and tradition.
Coors remained family-owned for over a century.
In 1959, it became the largest single-site brewery in the world.
Coors Light was introduced in 1978.
The company merged with Molson in 2005.
Despite Coors Light’s success, Banquet retained a distinct identity.
Coors was the first American brewery to establish an onsite recycling center.
It was the first to sell beer in all-aluminum cans in 1959.
Spent grain from brewing is reused to feed local livestock.
Coors installed pollution control equipment earlier than many competitors.
Banquet was bottled in recyclable glass before it became industry standard.
Coors Banquet is often seen as a symbol of the American West.
It is especially popular in Colorado, Texas, and the Mountain West.
The beer is nicknamed the “Cowboy Beer.”
Coors Banquet has a loyal following among military veterans.
It has long been associated with blue-collar culture.
Coors faced boycotts in the 1970s and 1980s over labor and LGBTQ+ issues.
Activist César Chávez supported boycotts against Coors.
The company later worked to rebuild its public image through inclusivity.
Coors once refused to unionize, sparking national protests.
Political donations by Coors executives stirred controversy in the 1980s.
Adolph Coors II died in a fall from a hotel window in 1929.
Adolph Coors III was kidnapped and murdered in 1960.
The Coors family has remained influential in conservative politics.
Bill Coors oversaw major expansion in the 1970s.
Peter Coors ran for U.S. Senate in 2004.
Vintage Coors Banquet cans are highly collectible.
Limited-edition heritage cans are released for anniversaries.
Older packaging featured the slogan “Brewed with Rocky Mountain Spring Water.”
Retro Banquet packaging is central to its nostalgic appeal.
Vintage Americana trends have revived interest in Banquet.
Kevin Costner and the cast of “Yellowstone” drink Banquet on screen.
Cowboy-core aesthetics helped fuel Banquet’s modern resurgence.
Social media introduced Banquet to Gen Z and Millennials.
Craft beer fans often respect Banquet for its consistency.
Coors Banquet is brewed exclusively in Golden, Colorado.
The brewery uses Moravian barley grown specifically for Coors.
The brewing process takes around 30 days.
The yeast strain has remained unchanged since the 1930s.
Ceramic filters are used in the brewing process.
Coors Banquet sponsors rodeos, rallies, and western festivals.
It has been a longtime sponsor of NASCAR and bull riding.
Banquet is often served at the Sturgis Motorcycle Rally.
The company supports wildland firefighter relief funds.
In 2023, Coors celebrated its 150th anniversary.
Legal battles once prevented Coors from shipping to some states.
Some states once deemed Coors “too fresh” for safe distribution.
Limited access led to black-market bootlegging.
In the 1970s, bringing Coors east was seen as a status flex.
The Golden brewery is a major tourist destination.
The site spans over 1,700 acres of land.
The Coors mansion still stands as a landmark in Golden.
The brewery generates steam energy onsite.
Elvis Presley was reportedly a fan of Coors Banquet.
A brewery-only Banquet with extra malt was once released.
Coors helped develop early beer cooling systems in the 1930s.
Coors Banquet has been served on U.S. Navy ships.
A version was once marketed as a “diet beer” in the 1960s.
Banquet is exported to Canada, Japan, and Europe.
Overseas marketing emphasizes American heritage.
Banquet is priced as a premium import in some countries.
Before refrigeration, Banquet was stored in underground caverns.
Merch includes hats, flannels, belt buckles, and enamel mugs.
Coors Banquet appears in dozens of country songs.
There is an unofficial fan group called the “Banquet Boys.”
Some bartenders shorthand it as “Banq.”
